title: Parallel upload hangs curl if upload file not found

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is a computer software project providing a library and command-line tool for transferring data using various protocols.

vulnerability_information:
Attempting to upload (-T) a not found file with parallel (-Z) flag present, will cause curl to get stuck and never terminate, potentially stalling scripts that make use of this particular flags. 

curl -T blabla-notexists -Z upload.example.com www.google.com www.cnn.com www.apple.com


Same issue occurs if using -Z or --parallel flags.


$ curl -T blabla-notexists -Z upload.example.com www.google.com www.cnn.com www.apple.com
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
DL% UL%  Dled  Uled  Xfers  Live   Qd Total     Current  Left    Speed
--  --      0     0     1     0     1 --:--:--  0:00:01 --:--:--     0      curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information
curl: Can't open 'blabla-notexists'!
curl: try 'curl --help' or 'curl --manual' for more information



Doesn't happen with --parallel-max or --parallel-immediate flags.

Observing the network with tcpdump, shows NO traffic at all.


I suspect this is just an ordinary bug, but reporting it in case there is a security angle that might be present. Really the only obvious security issue is that curl will block possibly forever, and if curl tool is used inside a script or binary (via system() for example) could cause that script/binary to stop/block/hang.  In some cases, this could lead to a bad situation, leading to denial of service or loss of service availability for program/process/server/service using curl in such a way.

Not 100% sure, but I suspect that libcurl does not have this issue.  I could be wrong.


Steps to Reproduce:
Upload (-T) a file with curl while in parallel mode (-Z) and the upload file must not exist locally.

curl -T blabla-notexists -Z upload.example.com www.google.com www.cnn.com www.apple.com

## Impact

curl hangs leading to denial of service or loss of service availablity for script or binary using curl CLI tool.


Mitigation:
Don't use -Z parallel flag with -T upload flag.

Not 100% sure, but I suspect that libcurl does not have this issue. I could be wrong.

Upload (-T) a file with curl while in parallel mode (-Z) and the upload file must not exist locally.

curl -T blabla-notexists -Z upload.example.com www.google.com www.cnn.com www.apple.com

curl hangs leading to denial of service or loss of service availablity for script or binary using curl CLI tool.

activities.message: Yes, I confirm that the report addresses: Reproducible, Impact and In Scope.
activities.markdown_message: Yes, I confirm that the report addresses: Reproducible, Impact and In Scope.

activities.message: Curl source code is at latest version.
activities.markdown_message: Curl source code is at latest version.

activities.message: By the description, this looks like a bug and I cannot see how this is a security problem. Can you elaborate on how you see this causing security issues?
activities.markdown_message: By the description, this looks like a bug and I cannot see how this is a security problem. Can you elaborate on how you see this causing security issues?

activities.message: Solution proposed as a PR: https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/6141
activities.markdown_message: Solution proposed as a PR: https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/6141

activities.message:
I see the report is already closed, sorry about being slow to respond.  Anyway, glad a fix is available and was so easy to implement.

This is the response I was working on, most likely won't change your mind, but I put it out there just in case.
 

The only security concern possible is that curl stops and does not ever return, blocking whatever parent process/thread that triggered it, potentially leading to impacts to service availability of the system using curl.


From the interactive CLI point of view that is not a problem as a user would just hit CTRL-C and they are out of the situation.  The errors reported should give the user a good clue to what is going on.

For persistent long running systems that have been designed to use the curl cli tool (instead of the proper libcurl), they are at risk when curl blocks.

These systems could over time accumulate a large number of curl processes that are hanging, potentially exhausting system resources, leading to a system crash/hang, denial of service, or loss of system availability.   Alternatively, in a different application type maybe only one curl process might end up blocking, but that curl process is in a critical thread of the application, rendering the system stalled until it unblocks.


Yes, I would agree that there should be some mitigations (for example, curl's own --max-time flag) that should prevent such process blocking issues from causing serious problems to an application. Unfortunitely, the --max-time flag does not work with this bug, it appears to be only in play during actual network transfers.  So only a careful developer using something outside of curl, like the coreutils "timeout" tool, could really prevent curl from blocking forever.  For argument sake, they did not implement such external mitigations.


An at risk application must:

1- be long running, able to accumulate threads where curl CLI has been executed and are stuck due to this bug.
   1.1- or a single stuck thread is critical to the operation of the application
2- allow in some fashion, users passing in the file name of a file(s) to be uploaded by curl.
3- the application does not check that the file exists before passing it to curl for upload.
   3.1- or the application does check that the file exists, but the file can be deleting by a malicious user before curl can act on it.
4- be using the parallel transfer option when the situation occurs, maybe the application always use it on the cmd line or via the default config file.
5- No mitigation in place to prevent curl hanging to cause problems.



Combining all these requirements is probably limited in scope ; and/or not the responsibility of curl to protect against, so the likelihood of a security issue might be low to none.
activities.markdown_message:
I see the report is already closed, sorry about being slow to respond. Anyway, glad a fix is available and was so easy to implement.

This is the response I was working on, most likely won't change your mind, but I put it out there just in case.

The only security concern possible is that curl stops and does not ever return, blocking whatever parent process/thread that triggered it, potentially leading to impacts to service availability of the system using curl.

From the interactive CLI point of view that is not a problem as a user would just hit CTRL-C and they are out of the situation. The errors reported should give the user a good clue to what is going on.

For persistent long running systems that have been designed to use the curl cli tool (instead of the proper libcurl), they are at risk when curl blocks.

These systems could over time accumulate a large number of curl processes that are hanging, potentially exhausting system resources, leading to a system crash/hang, denial of service, or loss of system availability. Alternatively, in a different application type maybe only one curl process might end up blocking, but that curl process is in a critical thread of the application, rendering the system stalled until it unblocks.

Yes, I would agree that there should be some mitigations (for example, curl's own --max-time flag) that should prevent such process blocking issues from causing serious problems to an application. Unfortunitely, the --max-time flag does not work with this bug, it appears to be only in play during actual network transfers. So only a careful developer using something outside of curl, like the coreutils "timeout" tool, could really prevent curl from blocking forever. For argument sake, they did not implement such external mitigations.

An at risk application must:

1- be long running, able to accumulate threads where curl CLI has been executed and are stuck due to this bug.
1.1- or a single stuck thread is critical to the operation of the application
2- allow in some fashion, users passing in the file name of a file(s) to be uploaded by curl.
3- the application does not check that the file exists before passing it to curl for upload.
3.1- or the application does check that the file exists, but the file can be deleting by a malicious user before curl can act on it.
4- be using the parallel transfer option when the situation occurs, maybe the application always use it on the cmd line or via the default config file.
5- No mitigation in place to prevent curl hanging to cause problems.

Combining all these requirements is probably limited in scope ; and/or not the responsibility of curl to protect against, so the likelihood of a security issue might be low to none.

activities.message: If you are sure there is no security issue, then I'm Ok to disclose when you are.
activities.markdown_message: If you are sure there is no security issue, then I'm Ok to disclose when you are.
